module.title: Core Wounds
module.description: Identify and understand the foundational emotional wounds that shape your reactive patterns and beliefs about self

teaching.heading: Understanding Core Wounds
teaching.content:
A core wound is not just a bad memory. It's a belief about yourself that was formed before you had language to question it.

Most core wounds form between ages 0-7, in moments when your developing brain needed to make sense of confusing or painful experiences. You were too young to think, 'My parent is having a hard day and is projecting their stress onto me.' Instead, you thought, 'I did something wrong. I am bad.'

That belief—'I am bad,' 'I am not enough,' 'I am unlovable,' 'I cannot trust'—became your core wound. It settled into your nervous system, your body, your sense of self. And from that day forward, you filtered reality through that belief.

Core wounds are not your fault. They are the result of a child's brain trying to survive in an imperfect world. But now, as an adult, they run your life from the shadows. They determine how you react to criticism, how you show up in relationships, what you believe you deserve, and what you're afraid to risk.

The good news: What was learned can be unlearned. What was formed can be reformed. But first, you must identify the wound. You must bring it into the light. That's the work of this module.
keyPoints: Core wounds are pre-verbal beliefs formed in early childhood
They're survival responses, not truth
They filter how you perceive reality as an adult
Identifying your wound is the first step to freedom

practice.title: Body Scan for Protection Patterns
practice.description: Lie down comfortably. Bring awareness to your body. Where do you feel tension? Tightness? Guarding? Your body knows where your wounds live—they're the places you protect. Breathe into each area. Ask: 'What are you protecting me from?' Listen without judgment.

journaling.prompt: When I feel 'not enough,' 'unlovable,' or 'unsafe,' what age do I feel like? What does that younger version of me need to hear?
questions: What beliefs about myself do I hold that I've never questioned?
If I trace my deepest fear back to childhood, what event or pattern do I find?
What would my life look like if I didn't believe this wound was true?

teaching.heading: A Framework for Understanding Your Wounds
teaching.content:
While each person's experience is unique, research in developmental psychology has identified five core wound types that most people carry. These are based on Lise Bourbeau's work and validated across countless therapeutic approaches.

1. REJECTION - 'I don't belong': The belief that you are fundamentally unwanted or that there's something wrong with who you are at your core. Often forms when a child feels rejected for simply existing.

2. ABANDONMENT - 'I will be left': The terror of being alone or left behind. This wound creates desperate clinging or preemptive abandonment of others before they can leave you.

3. HUMILIATION - 'I am shameful': The belief that you are inherently dirty, wrong, or disgusting. Often forms around bodily functions, sexuality, or needs being shamed.

4. BETRAYAL - 'I cannot trust': The wound that forms when trust is broken by someone you depended on. Creates hypervigilance and difficulty surrendering control.

5. INJUSTICE - 'I am not treated fairly': The wound of not being seen, valued, or treated with fairness. Creates rigid perfectionism and emotional coldness.

Most people have one or two primary wounds, with others as secondary. Each wound creates its own protective 'mask'—a personality adaptation designed to prevent the wound from being triggered.
keyPoints: Most people have 1-2 primary wounds from these five types
Each wound has a protective 'mask' or adaptation
You can't heal what you can't name
Recognition is the first step toward integration

practice.title: Wound Resonance Rating
practice.description: Read each wound description again slowly. Rate each one from 1-10 based on how strongly it resonates in your body (not your mind). Trust your first instinct. Notice which description makes your heart race, your stomach clench, or brings tears. That's your body speaking.

journaling.prompt: Which wound description made my body react most strongly? What sensations did I notice?
questions: Which wound feels most familiar, like an old companion?
What protective behaviors have I developed around this wound?
How has this wound shaped my relationships, career, and self-image?

teaching.heading: Following the Thread Back to the Source
teaching.content:
Your primary wound shows up everywhere. It's the recurring theme in your life story, the pattern you can't seem to break, the fear that underlies all other fears.

To identify your primary wound, look for these markers:

RECURRING RELATIONSHIP PATTERNS: Do you always feel abandoned? Betrayed? Not seen? The pattern that repeats across multiple relationships points to your core wound.

EMOTIONAL TRIGGERS: What makes you disproportionately reactive? When do you go from 0 to 100 emotionally? The trigger is often touching your wound.

SOMATIC RESPONSES: Where does your body contract or guard when you're stressed? Your wound lives in your body as much as your mind.

CHILDHOOD MEMORIES: What's your earliest painful memory? While one event doesn't create a wound, the earliest memory often points to the wound's theme.

SELF-BELIEFS: Complete this sentence: 'Deep down, I'm afraid I am...' The word that comes up is often your core wound speaking.

Your primary wound is not a life sentence. It's simply the belief system you've been operating from. Now that you're beginning to see it, you can start to question it.
keyPoints: Your primary wound shows up as recurring patterns
It creates disproportionate emotional reactions
Your body holds the wound somatically
Recognizing the pattern begins to break its power

practice.title: Childhood Memory Exploration
practice.description: Close your eyes. Ask your unconscious: 'Show me a memory that holds my core wound.' Don't force it—let a memory arise naturally. It might not be the 'worst' thing that happened. It's often a small moment that encoded a big belief. Stay with the memory. What did young-you conclude about yourself in that moment?

journaling.prompt: Complete this sentence in as many ways as possible: 'I am afraid that I am...'
questions: What memory arose in the meditation? What belief did I form about myself?
What pattern keeps repeating in my life that I've never named before?
If my wound had a voice, what would it be saying to me right now?

teaching.heading: Understanding Your Protective System
teaching.content:
In Module 1, you learned about parts—the fragmented aspects of yourself frozen in time. Now we're going to look at how your core wound created specific protective parts.

Using the Internal Family Systems (IFS) model, there are two types of protectors:

MANAGERS: These parts work proactively to prevent your wound from ever being triggered. They control, plan, perfect, people-please, withdraw, or overachieve. Managers say: 'If I can just control everything, I'll never feel that wound again.'

Examples:
- Perfectionist (preventing humiliation)
- People-pleaser (preventing rejection/abandonment)
- Controller (preventing betrayal)
- Achiever (proving you're not 'not enough')

FIREFIGHTERS: These parts activate when your wound is triggered despite the managers' efforts. They numb, distract, or discharge the pain through impulsive behaviors. Firefighters say: 'I'll do anything to not feel this wound right now.'

Examples:
- Substance use
- Binge eating or restriction
- Rage outbursts
- Sexual compulsion
- Dissociation

These protectors are not bad. They saved you when you were too young to protect yourself. But now, as an adult, they often cause more harm than the original wound would. The key is not to eliminate protectors, but to update them—to let them know you're no longer a helpless child.
keyPoints: Protectors are not the enemy—they saved you once
Managers prevent wounds from being triggered
Firefighters numb pain when wounds are activated
Understanding their origin allows you to update them

practice.title: Parts Dialogue with a Protector
practice.description: Identify one protective behavior you use often (perfectionism, people-pleasing, withdrawal, substance use, etc.). Write a dialogue with this part. Ask: 'What are you protecting me from?' 'How old do you think I am?' 'What do you need to know about me now?' Let the part answer—write whatever comes without censoring.

journaling.prompt: What behavior do I use most often to protect my core wound? When did I first develop this?
questions: What would happen if I stopped using this protective behavior?
What is this protector afraid of?
How can I thank this part for protecting me, while also letting it know I'm safe now?

teaching.heading: Seeing the Pattern Across Time
teaching.content:
Core wounds don't form from a single event. They're reinforced across childhood through multiple experiences that confirm the same belief.

Today, you'll create a wound timeline—a map of 3-5 significant moments where your core wound was formed or reinforced. This practice helps you see that your wound is not who you are; it's a belief system built over time.

As you identify these moments, look for the through-line—the recurring message your developing brain internalized:
- 'See? I knew I wasn't enough.'
- 'This proves I can't trust anyone.'
- 'I knew I didn't belong.'

The wound doesn't care about the details of what happened. It only collects evidence for its core belief.

IMPORTANT: This is not about blaming parents or caregivers. Most core wounds form not from malicious intent, but from unavoidable circumstances—a parent's own wounds, poverty, illness, absence, cultural conditioning. The goal is not to assign blame but to see clearly: This is where the belief came from. And if it came from outside me, it's not the truth of who I am.

Seeing the pattern breaks its invisibility. What you can see, you can begin to heal.
keyPoints: Wounds form through repeated experiences, not single events
Each experience confirms the same core belief
Seeing the pattern across time breaks its power
This is about clarity, not blame

practice.title: Wound Timeline Creation
practice.description: This is intensive work—give yourself time and space. Draw a timeline from birth to present. Mark 3-5 moments when you felt your core wound most intensely. For each moment, write: (1) What happened, (2) How old you were, (3) What you concluded about yourself. Then look for the through-line—the repeating message. This is your wound speaking, not truth speaking.

journaling.prompt: List 3-5 moments when you felt the wound most intensely. What was the recurring message?
questions: What through-line do I see across all these moments?
If this belief came from these experiences, not from truth, what becomes possible?
What would I need to believe instead to be free of this wound?

teaching.heading: Holding Yourself with Tenderness
teaching.content:
You've spent five days identifying, naming, and mapping your core wound. This work is not easy. If you're feeling raw, tender, or overwhelmed—that's normal. You're touching something that's been hidden for decades.

Now comes the most important part: self-compassion.

Self-compassion is not self-pity ('Poor me, I'm so wounded'). It's not self-indulgence ('I deserve to do whatever I want because I'm hurt'). It's also not spiritual bypassing ('Everything happens for a reason, so my wound is a gift').

Self-compassion, as defined by researcher Kristin Neff, has three components:

1. SELF-KINDNESS: Treating yourself with the same tenderness you'd offer a hurt child. Speaking to your wounded parts with gentleness, not judgment.

2. COMMON HUMANITY: Recognizing that core wounds are universal. You are not uniquely damaged. This is part of being human.

3. MINDFULNESS: Holding your pain without exaggerating it or suppressing it. Not drowning in the wound, but not pretending it isn't there.

The wounded part of you is frozen in time, still living in that childhood moment. It doesn't know you're an adult now. It needs to hear from your adult self: 'I see you. I'm here. You're not alone anymore. We're safe now.'

Compassion is what thaws what shame has frozen.
keyPoints: Self-compassion is not self-pity or indulgence
The wounded part is still a child, frozen in time
Compassion has three elements: kindness, common humanity, mindfulness
Compassion thaws what shame keeps frozen

practice.title: Loving-Kindness for Your Wounded Self
practice.description: Close your eyes. Visualize yourself at the age when your core wound was forming. See young-you clearly. Notice what you're wearing, where you are, how small you are. Now, as your adult self, approach young-you. Kneel down to their level. Place your hand on their heart. Say: 'I see you. I know it hurts. You're not alone anymore. I'm here now, and I will never leave you.' Let yourself feel whatever arises—grief, relief, tenderness.

journaling.prompt: What would I say to my 5-year-old self experiencing this wound for the first time?
questions: What does my wounded part need to hear that they never heard?
How can I offer myself the compassion I needed then, now?
What happens in my body when I imagine holding my younger self with tenderness?

teaching.heading: The Path Forward
teaching.content:
You've completed Module 2. You've identified your core wound, seen how it was formed, recognized how it created protective patterns, and offered yourself compassion. This is profound work.

But here's the truth: healing a core wound is not a one-time event. It's a practice, a commitment, a spiral journey.

Your wound was encoded over years. It won't vanish in seven days. But something has shifted: You've brought it into the light. You've named it. You've begun to separate the wound from your identity.

'I have a wound' is very different from 'I am wounded.'

As you move forward into Module 3 (Shadow Work & Radical Honesty), Module 4 (Inner Child Healing), and beyond, you'll continue working with this wound from different angles. Each module will add another layer of understanding and healing.

Healing is not linear. There will be days when you forget everything you've learned and fall back into the wound's story. That's not failure—that's being human. The practice is noticing: 'Ah, I'm in my wound right now.' And then choosing, in that moment, to respond differently.

The work ahead is this: Make a conscious choice. Will you continue to let your wound run your life from the shadows? Or will you commit to healing—to questioning the wound's beliefs, updating your protectors, and building new neural pathways based on truth, not childhood conclusions?

You've begun something profound. Don't stop now.
keyPoints: Healing core wounds is a practice, not a one-time fix
You've brought your wound into the light—that's the crucial first step
Healing is spiral, not linear—expect setbacks
The commitment is to notice the wound and choose differently

practice.title: Visualization - Your Future Healed Self
practice.description: Close your eyes. Imagine yourself at the end of this 16-module journey, 155 days from now. See yourself as someone who has done the deep work—someone who knows their wound but is no longer controlled by it. What does healed-you look like? How do they move through the world? How do they speak? What has become possible for them? Breathe into that vision. This is not fantasy—this is your potential.

journaling.prompt: What do I commit to as I continue this work? What support do I need?
questions: How has my understanding of myself shifted in these seven days?
What would my life look like if I wasn't run by my core wound?
What is one concrete practice I can take from this module into my daily life?
